layer.name: Sacrifice
layer.definition: Pour out for others with no expectation of return.

questions.text: Giving financial resources without expecting repayment is ...

answers.1: rare — I expect to be paid back

questions.text: Sharing physical resources (home, food, possessions) freely is ...

answers.4: common — my home and resources are open
answers.5: normal — everything I have is available
answers.3: moderate — I share when I have plenty

questions.text: Giving generously even when I can't see the difference it makes is ...

answers.4: common — I trust the giving matters
answers.5: expected — the giving is the point
answers.3: moderate — I give some on faith
answers.1: rare — I want to see impact

questions.text: Helping meet others' needs when my own resources are not abundant is ...

answers.4: common — I give from what I have
answers.5: expected — the widow's mite is the model
answers.1: rare — I give from excess only

questions.text: Having given to people who wasted it or rejected me (and would give again) is ...
questions.principle: True giving doesn't require good outcomes

answers.4: part of giving — I keep giving anyway
answers.1: not my experience — I vet recipients

remediation.advice: Financial and material sacrifice is the most tangible form of giving. It's also the area where hoarding is most tempting and visible. If you're not giving materially to others, examine why. Fear? Greed? Lack of trust in God's provision? Start where you are; give what you can.

scripture.text: Give, and it will be given to you. Good measure, pressed down, shaken together, running over, will be put into your lap.
